title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON – In the record books, it will be a 30-point victory for the Houston Rockets over the Toronto Raptors. But in the annals of basketball history, it will forever be remembered as the night Hakeem Olajuwon ascended to a rarefied peak.

The Rockets dismantled the Raptors 127-97, but the final score was a mere footnote to a singular, historic performance. Olajuwon, the game’s most graceful and dominant center, didn’t just play; he authored a masterpiece, becoming just the fourth player in NBA history to record a quadruple-double.

The stat line was staggering: 32 points, 10 rebounds, 11 assists, and a mind-boggling 10 blocked shots. Each category told a story of utter control. Offensively, "The Dream" was unstoppable, his array of post moves leaving Toronto defenders grasping at air. But it was his unselfishness, equaling a career-high 11 assists, that showcased his complete understanding of the game.

Yet, the true soul of his dominance was defensive. Olajuwon was an impenetrable fortress, swatting away 10 Raptors shots and altering countless others. The lane was a no-fly zone, his timing and anticipation transforming every Toronto drive into a perilous venture.

While Clyde Drexler provided steady support with 23 points and 9 assists, and Charles Barkley added a robust 17 points and 15 rebounds, they were orbiting planets to Olajuwon’s sun. The Raptors, led by Doug Christie’s 21 points, simply had no answer for the force of nature that wore number 34.

On this night, Hakeem Olajuwon didn’t just win a game; he etched his name alongside basketball’s immortals, delivering a performance of such rare and complete brilliance that it transcends the final score.
